metadata.title: Top 10 Business Intelligence Tools of 2020 | by Rashi Desai | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: In the rapidly growing world of today, when technology is expanding at a rate like never before, there are plenty of tools and skills to explore, learn, and master. In this digital and data age…

all_paragraphs: In the rapidly growing world of today, when technology is expanding at a rate like never before, there are plenty of tools and skills to explore, learn, and master. In this digital and data age, Business Information and Intelligence have climbed up the ladder of important business skills to a great extent, if

Business Intelligence can be weighed as important organizational competence these days! Organizations now propel their business far ahead of their competitors by potentially boosting brand awareness, internal engagement, organizational efficiency, and profitability with the help of BI.
The BI and analytics industry is expected to soar to a value of $26.50 billion by the end of 2021

Moreover, companies that use BI analytics are five times more likely to make swifter, more informed decisions. In that case, it is quintessential to embolden Business Intelligence skills. In this story, I have listed the top BI tools used in industries in 2020. There are a lot of BI tools existing and being used today but below are the most popular ones, in alphabetical order.

First rolled out in 2016, Google Data Studio might be the free, web-based suite that Google has to offer but Google’s user-friendly, intuitive design to business intelligence might be one of its strongest selling points.
Pros: Works great with data sourced from Google, like Google Analytics, Search Console, AdWords, YouTube analytics, and others. You can literally pull in any data you’d like from a Google Sheet.
Cons: Does not really help good to pull a big selection of pre-built connectors for data from other sources. Requires a lot to make working with a wide range of data types easy.

As for visualization and analysis capabilities, Data Studio offers a fair number of options compared to other analytics suites. One other potential drawback of Data Studio is the fact that it’s entirely web-based. Sharing is easy for those who are willing to head to the link you provide, but you won’t be able to export to a pdf or any other common reporting format, and automated report delivery is limited.
The quintessential business intelligence suite by IBM — Cognos Analytics is a cloud-based BI and analytics platform.

Cognos Analytics imports data from a wide variety of sources to help create interactive dashboards, visualizations, and reports. Its users are diverse; from enterprises in multiple industries and from small to large businesses.

IBM defines Cognos Analytics as an AI-infused decision-making tool. A very distinguishing feature of this platform is the use of a mobile app to view charts, receive alerts, and get real-time updates.

I never knew a BI tool like Looker existed until last week when I came across three entry-level full-time Data Analyst positions from Disney, Warner Media, and a local startup demanding proficiency with Looker. When I looked into Looker, it had to make it to the list of BI tools to know.

Looker is a browser-based business intelligence platform, simple to use, easy to choose, customize, and create a variety of interactive visualizations, providing a variety of graphs and charts to choose from. I am coming across a lot of comparisons between Tableau and Looker now.

The best feature I find about Looker is the drag and drop dashboard creation, which would prove to be a great help to non-technical users. Visualizations and reports are accessible on all devices and can be exported outside the Looker dashboard for collaboration with others too, a good feature to have?
Microsoft’s leading offering in the business intelligence tools space, Power BI, is designed to be useful for business analysts and data scientists.

I heard of Power BI in 2017 when I was interning with Larsen & Toubro, using Power BI for revenue expense analysis across departments, employee efficiency, real-time data processing for welding, and arching shifts.

With a simple drag-and-drop interface, PowerBI offers a sense of resemblance or familiarity to users of MS Excel. Power BI is a no-code platform and probably the reason behind its big hit. PowerBI has a great library of pre-built connectors, not as extensive as some of the other tools listed here, but Power BI will be a great add-on for any Windows-centric data workflow, especially in combination with Azure.

The Microsoft blog on Why Power BI explains very clearly and justifies why PowerBI is a de facto to Data Scientists. Power BI easily connects to, models, and visualizes data, creating memorable reports personalized with KPIs for a brand.
In my personal experience, PowerBI tends to lag on very large data sets, so you may want to look elsewhere if your data is really big.
Think of pie charts, line charts, pivot tables, bar charts, and more 📊, QlikView is a tool that is widely used across domains in the industry.

QlikView again is a Business Intelligence cum data discovery tool when the goal is to create guided analytics applications and dashboards for targeted business challenges. The software enables users to uncover data insights and relationships across various variables.

There has been quite a debate on the popularity of QlikView. While Tableau has big brands in the pocket, QlikView uses an in-memory data model making it capable of manipulating huge data sets instantly with accuracy which is Tableau’s scope of improvement.

SAP HANA (High-Performance Analytic Appliance) is an RDBMS, developed and marketed by SAP. Its primary function as a database server is to store and retrieve data as requested by supporting applications.

SAP HANA, an ETL based replication uses SAP Data Services to migrate data from SAP or non-SAP source to target the HANA database. Businesses using SAP in their biosphere use HANA to process massive amounts of real-time data in a short time.
Because SAP is a closed-source ecosystem, HANA might not be a tool for independent Data Scientists but for business or careers in SAP, HANA can be a good skill to flaunt.

Alike R, SAS is a tool developed for advanced data analysis and complex statistical operations. It is a closed-source proprietary tool that offers a wide variety of statistical capabilities to perform complex modeling. SAS is mostly used by large scale organizations and professionals due to its high reliability.

While SAS is not a tool best suited for beginners and independent data science enthusiasts it SAS is tailor-made to meet advances business demands, if you are looking to specific Data Science roles in your career, a good knowledge of SAS would gleam your profile.

SAS has been an undisputed market leader in the enterprise analytics space, however, to compare its capabilities with Python or R, SAS may seem difficult to model and visualize data with. Plus, the learning curve is tricky, difficult sometimes, and is mostly used by large corporations with huge budgets.

Tableau is a very popular and powerful data visualization tool used in Business Intelligence these days. Data analytics is rapid and robust with Tableau. With the visualization dashboards and worksheets, Tableau covers simplifying raw data into a very easily understandable format, cleaning data, and identifying underlying trends and patterns.

For quite some time now, big firms like PepsiCo, Verizon, Charles Schwab, Coca-Cola, Chipotle are using Tableau to leverage their data and make conclusive informed decisions. A tool like a Tableau is a must-know for anyone interested in a Data Science or Data Analytics career.

Spotfire was a business intelligence company based in Somerville, Massachusetts that was bought by TIBCO in 2007 (Wikipedia). Spotfire comes with the same general visualization capabilities as Tableau or QlikView.

While Tableau Public and Power BI Desktop is free to use, TIBCO Spotfire pricing starts at $650.00 per year, per user. There is no free version which might make it a less popular amongst independent Data Scientists. However, I recently came across this story on how Accor Hotels used TIBCO Spotfire to improve customer experience, and faster, easier, simpler integration.
TIBCO, an originally global leader in integration and analytics had a huge clientele with Spotfire in the kitty. You can visit the TIBCO customer list here.

Zoho, a web-based online office suite offers a self-service business intelligence platform called Zoho Analytics. It is a cloud-based platform with an option for on-premise installation. Zoho connects to a wide variety of sources to collect data. It can auto-merge data from popular business software or via Zoho’s self-service tools. The data stays in the US data center.

Zoho Analytics has 500 thousand businesses in its kitty, about 2M users, and 50M reports. From my research, I found Zoho Analytics to have the most comprehensive 3rd party connectors — 500+ out-of-the-box integrations for business apps! Do check this tool out.
That’s it from my end for this blog. Thank you for reading! I hope this helped! Do let me know what BI tool you are looking up to learn or explore.
Disclaimer: The views expressed in this article are my own and do not represent a strict outlook.

Rashi is a graduate student at the University of Illinois, Chicago. She loves to visualize data and create insightful stories. When not rushing to meet school deadlines, she adores writing about technology, UX, and more with a good cup of hot chocolate.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Healthcare Data Analyst from Chicago & Top 100 writer on Medium. Everyone loves a good story & I tell mine with data!
